Award.AwardTitle: Toward the Design and Control of Dynamical Transport Barriers in Nonlinear Flow

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fluid flows in natural and engineered systems, such as those in the ocean, atmosphere, or industrial machinery, are typically complex and variable in both space and time. Such flows mix efficiently on average, and they rapidly disperse material that they carry with them. They do not, however, mix uniformly. Rather, they spontaneously form complex patterns that lead to persistent inhomogeneities. In an oil spill, for example, oil does not move away uniformly from its source; instead, the oil wanders out in tendrils and whorls that are locked to the underlying structure of the ocean surface flow. In recent years, powerful methods have been developed to uncover the hidden structures that govern mixing in unsteady flows, and to isolate the transport barriers that separate different regions of the flow. Almost nothing is known, however, about how to control the location or presence of these dynamical barriers, or even whether it is possible to do so. This award will support research to demonstrate that control of these barriers is indeed possible, and to understand how barriers respond to external forces or to the shape of the container holding the fluid. The results of this research will have significant implications in a range of applications. For example, knowing how barriers in the ocean are related to coastline shape will inform the siting of coastal facilities that may discharge waste products or the deployment of limited resources in an environmental disaster. In other situations, such as in industrial mixers, rapid mixing is desirable, and so understanding how to inhibit the formation of transport barriers would be valuable.

Existing methods for locating transport barriers often require knowledge of the future evolution of the flow, and so have limited utility as predictive tools. This research will surmount this limitation by asking not how barriers will evolve naturally but rather how they can be manipulated and controlled. Two ways to control transport barriers will be investigated in an electromagnetically driven laboratory flow: control via spatio-temporally modulated applied body forces and control via lateral and bottom boundary shape. By demonstrating how transport barriers respond to manipulation of these quantities rather than to an imposed control velocity field, which is difficult to achieve in practice, the results of the research will pave the way for the development of implementable control strategies for real-world situations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chaotic and turbulent fluid flows are tremendously common in both the natural world and in engineered systems. One of the consequences of this turbulent motion is that material carried by these flows tends to mix very efficiently. Sometimes, this is desirable, such as in industrial mixers; but sometimes, we would prefer to suppress mixing, such as during environmental disasters such as oil spills.

 

Predicting the general behavior of turbulent flows remains next to impossible to do in detail in most practical situations. For characterizing mixing alone, however, significant progress has been made by adapting techniques from dynamical systems theory. In particular, researchers have learned a great deal about the ways that so-called coherent structures and transport barriers spontaneously created by turbulent flows guide mixing. 

 

The primary goal of this project was to build on this knowledge base and discover how these structures are controlled by forcing and boundaries. Understanding these links is a first step toward control controlling mixing in detail. To achieve this goal, we conducted laboratory experiments where we could control the shape of the lateral and bottom boundaries and the spatiotemporal structure of the driving forces. In addition to determining how these factors affected coherent structures, we also defined new kinds of structures, understood how they contribute to the turbulence dynamics, and studied fundamental aspects of 2D turbulence. 

 

To understand how the shape of the bottom and side boundaries affects transport, we inserted different lateral and bottom boundaries into our experimental flow cell and computed how transport barriers responded to them. For coastline-like lateral boundaries, we found that headlands tend to pin transport barriers. This has the effect of suppressing mixing and transport parallel to the coastline even far away from the coast itself. In contrast, embayments tend to suppress mixing in the perpendicular direction by capping the embayment with a dynamical barrier. We followed up this study by determining how features on the bottom of the flow affected the mixing at the surface. We showed that transport across a sharp bottom dropoff (analogous to a continental shelf break) was suppressed by the formation of a ?porous? transport barrier. Additionally, we found that the transport across the barrier was asymmetric: fluid moved preferentially from higher-turbulence regions to more weakly turbulent regions. Both of these studies demonstrate that lateral and bottom features play a significant role in guiding transport and mixing of surface waters, with clear application to coastal regions. Although the shape of the bottom and of the coastline cannot typically be controlled or changed, our results may have implications for the siting of coastal facilities that discharge effluents into the ocean and expect them to mix. 

 

In addition to these studies, we also developed new ways of thinking about coherence. Coherent structures have traditionally been defined as parts of the flow that look similar over some time span. But coherence should also suggest some degree of predictability: if the flow in some region is coherent, then we ought to be able to predict how the whole region will move knowing about only part of it. We developed this idea into a mathematically precise definition of what we termed linear neighborhoods (LNs). LNs are defined as regions whose behavior can be predicted up to a specified tolerance using linear extrapolation from a single point. We also showed that LNs play an unexpectedly important role in the turbulence dynamics. Subsequently, we refined our LNs using another newly developed analysis tool that we termed stochastic sensitivity to remove the arbitrariness in defining the error tolerance. Structures defined in this way appear to be excellent candidates for the formulation of reduced models of turbulent flow.

 

Finally, we made progress on fundamental aspects of turbulence in nearly two-dimensional geometries. Turbulence is notoriously difficult to define precisely, but one of its key features is the existence of a coherent flux of energy from the injection scales to the dissipation scales. We studied the details of the energy transfer process and how it is affected by the local flow properties. We defined an ?efficiency? for turbulent energy transfer, and found that turbulence is surprisingly inefficient. These ideas have led to a significant amount of follow-on research. We the applied similar logic to the way that enstrophy (an energy-like quantity associated with rotation in the flow) is transported between scales, identifying physical mechanisms driving this process. Finally, we studied in detail the way that energy is dissipated in our experimental system.

 

This project had several broader impacts. In addition to deepening our understanding of coherent structures in turbulent flows, the results of our work may prove valuable for engineers designing and siting coastal facilities. Our results may also lead to new ways of modeling turbulent flows. Finally, this project supported the training of a young researcher, who has now begun a faculty position.
